marytts.signalproc.filter
Class FIRFilter

java.lang.Object
  marytts.signalproc.filter.FIRFilter
All Implemented Interfaces:
InlineDataProcessor
Direct Known Subclasses:
AveragingFilter, BandPassFilter, BandRejectFilter, HighPassFilter, LowPassFilter
public class FIRFilter
extends java.lang.Object
implements InlineDataProcessor

Author:
Marc Schröder A filter corresponding to a finite-impulse-response LTI system. The filtering of the input signal corresponds to a convolution with the impulse response of the system.

FIRFilter

public FIRFilter(double[] impulseResponse)
Create a new Finite Impulse Response filter.

Parameters:
impulseResponse - the impulse response signal

FIRFilter

Method Detail

initialise

protected void initialise(double[] impulseResponse,
                          int sliceLen)
Initialise the Finite Impulse Response filter.

Parameters:
impulseResponse - the impulse response signal
sliceLength - the length of the slices in which to process the input data. IMPORTANT: impulseResponse.length+sliceLength must be a power of two (256, 512, etc.)
Throws:
java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if the slice length is shorter than the impulse response length, or it the sum of both lengths is not a power of two.

apply

public DoubleDataSource apply(DoubleDataSource signal)
Apply this filter to the given input signal. The input signal is filtered piece by piece, as it is read from the data source returned by this method. This is the recommended way to filter longer signals.

Parameters:
signal - the signal to which this filter should be applied
Returns:
a DoubleDataSource from which the data can be read

apply

public double[] apply(double[] signal)
Apply this filter to the given input signal. This method filters the entire signal, and returns the entire filtered signal. For long signals, it is better to use apply(DoubleDataSource).

Parameters:
signal - the signal to which this filter should be applied
Returns:
the filtered signal.
